III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157(1)(e)
Section Health services; policies and procedures.
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A is prescribed medication that is to be taken at bedtime,
however, the facility is giving Youth A his medication at 5:00pm.
This has caused Youth A to be zoned out for the rest of the
evening and Youth A has lost weight due to a lack of appetite
which is a side effect of the medication.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 10/2/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Registered Nurse 1 (RN) was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility in collaboration with MDHHS Worker on 8/27/2025. RN
1 stated she is employed through Vital Core which has a contract
with the facility. She has been employed since December 2024
and her schedule is Monday-Friday, 7:30am-5:00pm. She stated
there are other nurses employed through Vital Core that assist this
facility, but she is the main nurse for the facility. RN 1 stated she
passes medications to youth around 8:00am and then again at
around 4:45pm and passing medications is the last thing she does
before she leaves. She stated some youth may have a midday
medication and that is dispensed around 1:00pm. She stated if a
youth is prescribed medication to be taken at bedtime, they will
get their medication around 4:45pm due to her shift ending. She
stated on the weekends; there is another employee from Vital
Core who will pass out the medications. She stated Youth A is
prescribed Risperdal, Guanfacine and Trazedone. Trazedone is
prescribed at bedtime, but provides Youth A this medication
before 5:00PM, and Risperdal and Guanfacine are only prescribed
for twice a day. She stated Youth A takes Melatonin at his
mother’s request, and it is not a prescription. RN 1 stated she
informed Youth’s A mother several months ago of the times of
medication distribution and that a LPN or MA from the jail will
come over and complete medication distribution on the weekends.
RN 1 took Youth’s A vitals two weeks ago and there was no
change in his weight. RN 1 completes documentation when she
passes medications.
2

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaborations with MDHHS Worker on 8/27/2025. Youth A
stated he takes medication every day. He takes three pills in the
morning, and then 5 or 6 pills at 5:00pm. He stated he is aware
that one of his medications are to be taken before he goes to
sleep. He stated this medication is supposed to put him to sleep
but it is dispensed to him too early. Youth A stated his bedtime is
around 10:00pm. He stated he has only spoken to his mother
about it, but he has not brought it to the attention of staff at the
facility. He does recall starting the sleep medication in June 2025.
Youth A did state that he does receive all his medication. Youth A
did not know the names of his medication and stated his
medication is for anxiety, anger, and sleep. Youth A did not know
his diagnoses. Youth A stated he does receive 3 meals and 2
snacks every day. He stated he has not been eating all of his
meals because he doesn’t have an appetite due to being placed at
the facility.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility in collaboration with the MDHHS worker on 8/27/2025.
CA stated she was recently made aware of Youth A and possibly
other youth who are prescribed medication to be taken at bedtime
but is being dispensed between 4:45pm-5:00pm. CA stated she
will immediately be addressing this concern with Vital Core so that
a nurse may dispense medication to youth at the prescribed time.
CA stated only nurses staffed from Vital Core provide the
medication to the youth.

• Medical & Health Care Services – Use of
Pharmaceutical Products Policy:
o State and Federal regulations relating to the dispensing,
distributing and administering of medications shall be
followed. Medications shall be distributed or
administered only by assigned staff in accordance with
the physician's orders.
o PROCEDURES:
I. The medical staff shall require that all pharmacy
procedures adhere to applicable state and federal laws
and regulations.
2. Where prescriptions are generated by contract or
consultant health providers, substitutions may be made
in accordance with approved guidelines contained in the
Central Drug Formulary and approved by the facility's
physician.
B. Prescription Practices: All pharmaceutical shall be
prescribed in accordance with the Central Drug
4

Formulary which governs approved prescription and
nonprescription medications. Practices to be followed by
the health care staff include:
1. Discouraging the long term use of minor tranquilizers
and analgesics subject to abuse unless clinically
indicated.
2. Specifying "stop order" time periods for all behavior-
modifying medications and other medications subject to
abuse. A re-evaluation shall be performed by the facility
physician prior to the renewal of such prescriptions.
3. Dispensing psychotropic medications only when
clinically indicated.
When necessary, the patient shall be referred to a
psychiatrist for an evaluation of the patient's medication
needs.
4. Prescribing medications only upon the authorization
of the supervising physician. All verbal authorizations for
prescriptions must be signed by the physician within 24-
hours of such authorization.
5. Stimulants, tranquilizers and psychotropic drugs
requiring intramuscular administration are prescribed
and administered only by a physician.
6. Under no circumstances is a stimulant, tranquilizer of
psychotropic drug administered for purposes of program
management and control or for purposes of
experimentation and research.
7. All prescriptions shall be signed by a qualified health
professional licensed and authorized by the appropriate
jurisdiction.
• Medication Distribution or Administration:
I. No medication is to be administered to any juvenile
except:
a. On an individual (case-by-case) basis.
b. At prescribed times.
c. By a designated staff member (physician, licensed
nursing staff, or by other staff who have been trained in
medication administration).
d. As authorized by a medical doctor or dentist.
2. The administration of all medications shall be
recorded on a form approved by the medical staff and
shall become part of the juvenile's medical record. Each
dose shall be documented with the date and time of
administration and shall be signed or initialed by the
staff member administering it.
3. Any medication prepared for administration later in
the day or by another
5

staff member is to be placed in a container identified
with at least:
a. The juvenile's name, room number, and DOB.
b. The time and date the medication is to be
administered.
c. All special instructions.
d. The name of the person who prepared the
medication.
Analysis The agency is found to be in non-compliance of dispensing
medication. Youth A’s medications are prescribed to be taken
during bedtime, however his medication was dispensed to him
several hours before his bedtime.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10163
Section Personal hygiene
Description (1) An institution shall assure that each resident maintains or
receives personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate to the
resident's age, sex, race, cultural background, and health needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has not been receiving showers twice a day at the facility
due to a medical condition requirement.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 10/2/2025
and did not provide additional information.
Registered Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker on 8/27/2025. RN stated
Youth A’s Mother sent a court recommendation letter to Youth A’s
probation officer for him to receive two showers a day on
8/25/2025. RN stated she did speak to Youth A’s Mother on
8/22/2025 about the facility utilizing a tub so Youth A can soak his
wound. RN stated Youth A is taking his two showers a day and he
left the facility on Tuesday, August 26th in the morning to see his
surgeon. RN stated Youth A’s surgeon recommended Youth A
take two showers a day and use hair removal cream, which is in a
letter addressed to the facility and dated for 8/26/2025. RN stated
Youth A used the hair removal cream on 8/26/2025.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker on 8/27/2025. Youth A
stated he is taking showers twice a day and he used the hair
removal cream one time. Youth A stated there are no concerns to
report of him not receiving his twice a day showers.
6

Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility in collaboration with MDHHS Worker on 8/27/2025. CA
stated the agency did receive an email on 8/25/2025
recommending Youth A soak his wound or take showers twice a
day and to use Nair or hair removal surrounding the area of his
wound. The agency followed the recommendation immediately,
and Youth A has been receiving his twice daily showers and RN
bought and provided hair removal cream for Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• A letter written by Pediatric Surgeon dated for 8/18/2025:
“Youth A is under my care for recurrent pilonidal disease.
An important part of his treatment is the need to soak the
area or shower at least twice a day. Please allow Youth A
time to shower for 30 minutes twice a day”. This letter was
sent by Youth A’s mother to probation, and the facility
received the letter on 8/25/25.
• A letter written by Pediatric Surgeon, dated for 8/26/2025:
“An important part of Youth A’s treatment is the need to
soak the area or shower at least twice per day. Please
allow Youth A time to shower for 30 minutes twice a day.
Youth A also must be supplied Nair or another depilatory
cream to aid in hair removal of his surgical area.
• Juvenile Rights – Environmental & Programmatic Rights of
Juveniles:
o POLICY: All detained juveniles have certain rights and
responsibilities that must be recognized. These are clearly
defined, and both juveniles and staff shall be familiar with
them. Complaints of abridgment of the rights set forth
below shall be subject to the grievance process. Juveniles
who do not accept recognized responsibilities and resulting
in rule violation are subject to disciplinary process.
o Juvenile Rights:
6. Juveniles have the right to nutritious meals, proper
bedding and clean clothing, daily showers, toilet facilities,
adequate lighting, proper ventilation for warmth and fresh
air and an overall safe environment maintained in
compliance with state and local fire and safety laws and
regulations.
7. Juveniles have the right to appropriate medical and
dental treatment.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was insufficient
evidence to support a rule violation of staff at the facility not
providing Youth A with twice a day showers per his surgeon’s
recommendation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
